div.head:
Embleme 5. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Put a Toad upontothe womans breasts, that shee may give it sucke,
and the womandye herselfe, and the Toad be grassegrow fattwith milke.

lg.l: Lay the cold Toad to th' womans milky breast,
That as an infant hee himselfe may feast,
And thereby grow in bignesse and in strength,
Till hee hath killd his dry: suckd nurce at length:
An antidote, from theme praepare, the heart
Intoxicates cures, and pocks with art.

div.head: Discourse 5.
div.ab:
The whole troop of thephilosophers doe herein consent, that their worke is
nothing els, but man and wife: the mans part is indeed to generate, and governe
the wife, hers to conceive, be impraegnated, bring forth, give sucke, and educate
the offspring, and be subject to the mans comand: for as shee sustaines and
nourisheth the conceived Embryo, before it be brought to light, with blood, soe
being brought forth with milke. To this end Nature hath praepared for the
tender infant a digestible and proportioned food in the mothers breasts, which
waits his coming, as the first provision and viaticum in this race of the world:
by milke therefore hee is nourished, growes, and is increased, till hee be furnished
with instruments to chaw bread, that is, teeth, then is hee deservedly weaned, be
cause nature hath provided him other nutriment more solid: But here the phi
losophers say, that a Toad must be put to the womans breasts, that shee may
nourish it, as an infant, with her milke: This is a miserable and horrible spectacle,
yea and a wicked thing, that milke designed for an infant should be given to a
Toad, being a venomous beast, and contrary to the nature of man: Wee have
heard and read of Serpents and Dragons sucking the teats of cowes: Toads might
perhaps desire the same thing, if ocasion should be offered in beasts. There is a
noted story of a Toad, who seated himselfe upon the mouth, and inside of the
lipps of a certaine countryman being asleep, soe that hee could not be driven of
by any contrivance, unlesse by violence, which being accompanys with danger of
death, by the spitting of poyson (which hee is sayd to use for defensive or offensive
weapons) was therefore not to be attempted; but a remedy being found for the
miserable man by antipathy, namely, of a very great Spider and the Toad,
who hate one another mortally, hee was therefore carryd with the Toad di
rectly to the place, where an overcomeovergrowneSpider has made its webs, which
seing the Toad, praesently came downe upon the backe of the Toad, and
prickd him with its sting: but hee having received noe harme thereby, it
descended a second time, and strucke him againe more strongly, where
upon the Toad began imediately to swell, and fell downe dead from the
mans mouth, without any hurt to him. But here a thing contrary happens, be
cause the Toad seireth not the mouth but the breast of the woman, by whose milke hee
increaseth soe as to be of great magnitude and strength, but the woman consumes
and dyes her spirits being taken away: for poyson is easily comunicates by the pec
torall veins to the heart, and corrupts and destroyes it, as it is evident in the case of
Cleopatra, who applyes Vipers to her breasts, being willing to be praevented by voTheophilus in

querours: But lest any man should thinke the philosophers soe cruell, as to en
joyne a venomous reptile to be put to a woman, hee must know that this Toad
is the offspring or sonne of the same woman, produced by a monstrous birth,
and therefore by naturall right ought to be fed and nourished by the mothers
milke, but it is not in the will of the sonne that the mother should dye: for
neither could hee infect his mother, who was coagulated in her bowells, and
increases by blood even to birth. It is indeed a thing ominous for a Toad
to be borne of a woman, which in our knowledge hath happened elswhere:
Discourse 5.
Guilielmus Novobrigensis, an English writer, in his comentaryes sayth (how
truely let others judge) that in a certaine stone=quarry in the Diocesse of the
Bishop of Winchester, a great stone being divided, there was within found a living
Toad with a golden chaine, and it was by the Bishops comand hidden in the
same place, and buryd in perpetuall darknesse, lest it might bear an ill omen
with it: such is allso this Toad: for it is apparelled with gold, though not extrin
secally, with the artificiall worke of a chaine, yet intrisecally with a naturall,
namely of a stone, which some call Borax, Chelonitis, Batrachites, Crapaudina,
or Garatronium: for this farre excells gold in virtue against all poysons whatsoe
ver of animalls, and is comonly sett in gold, as a case or cover, that it may
not be hurt or lost. But it ought to be legitimate being had out of theananimall, but if
it be pickd out of subterranean trenches, as comonly it is, the stone taken up
may be made neat in the forme of it, and uses instead thereof with the best
mineralls, releiving and comforting the heart: for here in theseis the philosophicall
Toad is indeedreally found, not in a stone=quarry (as that fabler affirms) and hath
gold in him, not outwardly for pompe: for to what end should a Toad adorne
himselfe, lurking in darkenesse and secret places? that hee might perhaps
be magnificently saluted by a Beetle, if it mett him in the twylight? what
subterranean Goldsmith should make him a golden chayne? the father
perhaps of the green boyes, which came out of the land of St Martin, yea
out of the earth itselfe, as allso two doggs out of the stone=quarry, asserted
by the same Author?
